text:
There are many examples of children intuiting their way to these things in Kay's writing. I can vouch for this phenomenon as I ended up reinventing calculus at around eight years old to write little simulation programs using 1970s era 8-bit computers.

Expanding on what <@UA14TGLTC> says above, not only can the common notation and formula manipulation tricks can be learnt with little or no real intuitive understanding, but likewise the intuition can be learnt quite well without that notation. I would even go on to say that in most regards an executable notation is superior to the 19th century standard.

<http://vpri.org/pdf/rn2007006a_olpc.pdf>

text:
Hmm. When I think of "mathland" I think being embedded in an environment where you learn math through play as its primary feature, and its capacity to communicate the main ideas of a subject, calculus for example, as secondary. I also think of the concept as being applicable to every level of math and physics. I learn these things by playing around with them, and I find that some environments are more conducive than others. But all of these environments are theoretical ones existing in other peoples heads that are communicated through the normal symbolic, verbal, and occasionally visual channels. So I'm admittedly coming from a bit broader a place though. I just can't think of any other image that communicates the idea of math through play better than mathland, so I'm appropriating the idea to a degree.

Zooming back in a little, the main "feature" thats missing is proofs or an equivalent. I really could have asked what class of mathlands have these things. And the whole discussion could be much simplified by just considering Euclidean geometry for instance. And when I was mentioning the cycloid and parabola I was thinking of these as an extension of euclidean geometry, as done by archimedes and others before calculus. No symbolic machinery needed, but its probably all the harder for it and not at all realistic.

Another direction it can go is a mathland supplanting symbolic methods. Kill Math already provides some vocabulary for this, and I'd venture to say those methods can be just as powerful as the symbolic ones. After all, any variable is just a number that varries, and a function is just a number that varies with another number.

text: The most obvious approach I can picture would just be taking URL links that already exist as backlinks. Why would that need a critical mass of people contributing to it?

text:
Ah, got it, just turning existing links into backlinks, I had misunderstood you!

This is certainly possible, though there are some very real challenges!

• a bootstrap problem, if you care about links between different domains then it's always going to be incomplete, period, and it's probably going to miss the one important link you're looking for unless you're indexing most of the web. Indexing most of the web is quite expensive! So it'll be hard to get paying customers without first spending a lot of money.
• The web is mostly trash, so you'll need to put a lot of effort into filtering out the unimportant backlinks
• You'll probably never be able to index links from places like Facebook and Instagram, and it'll be very difficult to index links from places like Twitter. A large amount of activity goes on in there that you won't have access to!

text:
In a fundamental sense, it's not possible because linking is a one-way action. I can link to your website from an HTML file hosted off this laptop - how would you ever know?

In a practical sense you can probably get close because of how much tracking there is in the real internet. I would look into Google Analytics API for that. Or you could try some heuristic like the following Google search; `"<http://futureofcoding.org|futureofcoding.org>" -<site:futureofcoding.org>` which searches for a URL, excluding from that domain itself.
